description: a(n) (n>4) is least integer > a(n-1) with precisely two representations a(n) = a(i) + a(j), 1<=i<j<n.
references: S. R. Finch, Mathematical Constants, Cambridge, 2003, pp. 145-151.
R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, Section C4.
R. Queneau, Sur les suites s-additives, J. Combin. Theory, A12 (1972), 31-71.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..5440
mathematica: a[n_ /; n <= 4] = n; a[n_] := a[n] = Catch[ For[an = a[n-1] + 1, True, an++, cnt = 0; Do[If[an == a[i] + a[j], cnt++], {i, 1, n-1}, {j, i+1, n-1}]; If[cnt == 2, Throw[an]]]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 56}](* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Apr 30 2012 *)
prog: (Haskell)a003044 n = a003044_list !! (n-1)a003044_list = 1 : 2 : 3 : 4 : f [4,3..1] where   f xs@(x:_) = y : f (y : xs) where     y = head [w | w <- [x + 1 ..],         length [() | v <- xs, (w - v) `elem` dropWhile (>= v) xs] == 2]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 17 2013
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
